thread.title: Brad Rock: Utes' goals still intact, but they fail to make correction
thread.title_full: Brad Rock: Utes' goals still intact, but they fail to make correction | Deseret News

author: Brad Rock
title: Brad Rock: Utes' goals still intact, but they fail to make correction
text:
Almost a century after their last win at USC, the Utes are still looking to recover. But conference title and big bowls are still in play.
Upcoming Games Utah Football Utah football stats & schedule Ore. St. @ Utah Rice-Eccles Stadium, Salt Lake City Oct. 31, 5:00 p.m. 6 Days 7 Hrs 31 Mins 52 Secs More Coverage Sunday Morning QB: Stars and stats from No. 3 Utah's 42-24 upset loss at USC USC's Gustin, Masina happy to come out on top against their Utah brothers Utah's unbeaten season crumbles in L.A. as USC overpowers third-ranked Utes 42-24 Utah notebook: Hil makes it clear about wanting Whittingham to stay with the Utes “ They played good defense and had lot of great athletes on their team. I need to make smarter decisions.”
Travis Wilson
LOS ANGELES — In the 1983 film “Never Say Never Again,” a rakish James Bond finds himself on the wrong end of a training exercise that sees him knifed in the ribs while freeing a captive. He gets sent to a fitness camp to shape up for a final assignment.
Later he ends up saving the world from annihilation at the hands of yet another madman.
Did the USC Trojans write this, or was it just one of their many Movieland screenwriters? Two weeks after firing their coach, their season was on life support and what did they do?
Took out undefeated Utah, 42-24.
“Didn’t expect to get punched in the mouth like that,” said Ute linebacker Gionni Paul.
After 11 national championships and six Heisman winners, never assume they can’t pull off one more mission. Few people did, considering the Utes were underdogs even though they were ranked No. 3 nationally going into Saturday’s game.
The Utes thought they could conquer the world. The tough part is they ran into a one-man apocalypse, linebacker Cameron Smith, who intercepted three Travis Wilson passes.
“They played good defense and had lot of great athletes on their team. I need to make smarter decisions,” Wilson said.
So where do the Utes go from here? They’re hoping the same place they’ve been eyeing. One loss or none, they remain a contender for the conference title game, which could still mean a playoff berth or Rose Bowl appearance.
“Our main goal is to win the Pac-12 South and we’re still in the driver’s seat,” receiver Britain Covey said.
They rose from being unranked before the season began, to No. 3 in seven weeks.
USC? It brings a lot of worries for opponents, even on bad years.
The book on the Utes was if you let them play close throughout, they can beat anyone. But get them down early and force them to rush back and it’s a different story. That’s what happened. Wilson threw the last of four interceptions with two seconds remaining. But the finishing touch had come long before, when the Trojans drove for a fifth touchdown to go ahead 35-17.
No movie ending this time for the Utes. This one went straight to video.
In the film room. On Monday.
If coach Kyle Whittingham and his coordinators’ objective was to outsmart the Trojans, that didn’t happen. With 1:07 in the half, Utah gambled on fourth-and-two at the USC 45. Wilson rolled right and threw a pick-six to Smith.
That was the second interception of the half by Smith, who also brought back a pass to the Utah 4, setting up a 21-14 Trojan lead.
The half ended with the Utes in a position they feared: Down a couple of scores (28-17) and locked in a scoring festival. Their best plan is to get an early lead and let the defense do its job, not trail early and try to catch up.
The uneven outing overshadowed some fascinating moments in the early going. Late in the first quarter, Wilson hit Covey on a crossing route to tie the score at 7. Shortly after, Covey fielded a punt and quickly swerved right, then veered straight, then straight again. Then left and left again for a 40-yard run, to the USC 2.
He looked like a Californian taking the back streets to avoid traffic.
But shortly after, the Utes must have realized they were playing a team they hadn’t defeated in L.A. since 1916.
This is one reason the bookies in Vegas had the Utes 3½-point underdogs when the week began, despite the fact Utah came in ranked No. 3, with the Trojans unranked.
Meanwhile, Wilson finished 24-36 passing with four interceptions. Realistically, it was Wilson: a fair-to-middling quarterback whose experience doesn’t always outweigh the mistakes, but other times looks fine. His touchdown-to-interception ratio (2 to 4) stunk on Saturday. That’s not to be harsh on Wilson. He got the Ute record to 6-0. Seven-and-zero was asking a lot.
Though the loss stung, it didn’t end their aspirations in the big picture.
“It’s still a great season,” Wilson said. “We’re still in the top in the South, so we just want to make sure that we learn from this and make the corrections.”
When it comes to playing USC, they’ve been working on a correction for 99 years.
